natural problem:
Find $(-1)^{-10} + (-1)^{-9} + (-1)^{-8} + \cdots + (-1)^9 + (-1)^{10}$.

(The dots $\cdots$ mean that there are 21 numbers being added, one for each integer from $-10$ to 10.)
natural solution: Recall that $(-a)^n= a^n$ when $n$ is an even integer and $-a^n$ when $n$ is an odd integer. In particular, when $a=1$ this identity tells us that $(-1)^n = 1$ when $n$ is even and $-1$ when $n$ is odd.

This includes $(-1)^0 = 1.$  So the sum in question becomes \[ 1 + (-1) + 1 + (-1) + \cdots + 1 + (-1) + 1. \]Since $1 + (-1)=0$, we can add these numbers up in pairs to get  \[ \underbrace{1 + (-1)}_0 + \underbrace{1 + (-1)}_0 + \cdots + \underbrace{1 + (-1)}_0 + 1 = 0 + 0 + \cdots + 0 + 1 = \boxed{1}.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. -10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 10 \<longrightarrow> f n = (- 1) powr n"
shows  "sum f {-10..10} = 1"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find $(-1)^{-10} + (-1)^{-9} + (-1)^{-8} + \cdots + (-1)^9 + (-1)^{10}$.

(The dots $\cdots$ mean that there are 21 numbers being added, one for each integer from $-10$ to 10.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 Recall that $(-a)^n= a^n$ when $n$ is an even integer and $-a^n$ when $n$ is an odd integer. In particular, when $a=1$ this identity tells us that $(-1)^n = 1$ when $n$ is even and $-1$ when $n$ is odd.
 This includes $(-1)^0 = 1.$  So the sum in question becomes \[ 1 + (-1) + 1 + (-1) + \cdots + 1 + (-1) + 1. \]Since $1 + (-1)=0$, we can add these numbers up in pairs to get  \[ \underbrace{1 + (-1)}_0 + \underbrace{1 + (-1)}_0 + \cdots + \underbrace{1 + (-1)}_0 + 1 = 0 + 0 + \cdots + 0 + 1 = \boxed{1}.
 \]
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. -10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 10 \<longrightarrow> f n = (- 1) powr n"
shows  "sum f {-10..10} = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A function $f$ is defined on integers $n$ in the range $-10 \leq n \leq 10$ as $f(n) = (-1)^n$. What is the sum of $f(n)$ for $n$ from $-10$ to $10$? The final answer is $1$.

 \]

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"

shows  "(\<Sum>n = -10..10. f n) = 1"
 proof-

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "sum (\<lambda>i. (-1) powr i) {from = -10, to = 10}"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>i. (-1) powr i) {from = -10, to = 10} = 1"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find $(-1)^{-10} + (-1)^{-9} + (-1)^{-8} + \cdots + (-1)^9 + (-1)^{10}$.

(The dots $\cdots$ mean that there are 21 numbers being added, one for each integer from $-10$ to 10.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 Recall that $(-a)^n= a^n$ when $n$ is an even integer and $-a^n$ when $n$ is an odd integer. In particular, when $a=1$ this identity tells us that $(-1)^n = 1$ when $n$ is even and $-1$ when $n$ is odd.
 This includes $(-1)^0 = 1.$  So the sum in question becomes \[ 1 + (-1) + 1 + (-1) + \cdots + 1 + (-1) + 1. \]Since $1 + (-1)=0$, we can add these numbers up in pairs to get  \[ \underbrace{1 + (-1)}_0 + \underbrace{1 + (-1)}_0 + \cdots + \underbrace{1 + (-1)}_0 + 1 = 0 + 0 + \cdots + 0 + 1 = \boxed{1}.
 \]
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "sum (\<lambda>i. (-1) powr i) {from = -10, to = 10}"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>i. (-1) powr i) {from = -10, to = 10} = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Calculate the sum of $(-1)^i$ for all integers $i$ from -10 to 10. The final answer is 1.
